intro: Laphamia rupestris, commonly known as the rock dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of many small florets. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are basal, oblanceolate, and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow and appear in spring. Laphamia rupestris is adapted to drought conditions and is often found in desert or scrubland habitats.
